summary: This FBI Public Affairs briefing document summarizes a Miami Herald news report about two women who were sexually abused as teenagers by Jeffrey Epstein. They are requesting a hearing for all victims and are seeking to hold former prosecutor Alexander Acosta accountable for the 2007 non-prosecution agreement.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Multimillionaire financier who sexually abused teenage girls and received a non-prosecution agreement in 2007.

persons.name: Alexander Acosta
persons.role: Former federal prosecutor, Secretary of Labor
persons.context: As a federal prosecutor in Miami in 2007, he approved the non-prosecution agreement for Epstein. Victims are seeking to hold him accountable.

connections.description: Acosta, as a federal prosecutor, approved a non-prosecution agreement for Epstein in 2007, which victims are now challenging.

events.title: Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein received a non-prosecution agreement from federal prosecutors in Miami, led by Alexander Acosta, for sex crimes involving minors.

events.title: Victims' Request for Hearing
events.description: Two women who were sexually abused as teenagers by Epstein filed a request in court for a hearing for all victims and to hold prosecutors accountable.

keyFacts: Two women, sexually abused as teenagers by Jeffrey Epstein a decade ago, are requesting a federal hearing for all victims.
The victims are seeking to hold former prosecutor Alexander Acosta accountable for the 2007 non-prosecution agreement given to Epstein.
The legal battle by victims to imprison Epstein and hold prosecutors accountable has been ongoing for over a decade.
Alexander Acosta was the federal prosecutor in Miami who approved the non-prosecution agreement for Epstein in 2007.
The document is an FBI Public Affairs briefing summarizing a Miami Herald news report on the victims' legal actions.
